Body:
Yes there are!

Another common one is the partitive. If you've ever learned a language like French then it's an article you use with mass nouns like "water" or "cake". In English the closest would be something like "some" as in "Would you like some cake?". Occasionally you'll see it written by linguists as "sm", as it is phonologically reduced in speech.

Here are some examples from French:

  • Je ne bois pas de café.
  • Je n'ai pas de temps à perdre.
  • Donne-moi de la glace.

I'm sure there are probably others!

LastEditedUser.AboutMe:
Travelling armchair linguist.

Never studied in an institution but read books and web with probably more breadth than depth.

Always on the road surviving in a strange foreign language, currently Mongolian and Mandarin Chinese.

And I collect dictionaries.

OwnerUser.AboutMe: I have a PhD in linguistics. My areas of interest include language documentation, Tibeto-Burman linguistics, gesture, language play, LOLspeak, evidentiality and making bad puns. I blog about language and linguistics at www.superlinguo.com
